On Thu, 2003-07-17 at 12:47, Patel, Rakesh wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> what is the best way to verify database updates in the db? I really do not
> want to write jdbc code in the the JUnit cases if i can avoid it.
> 
> We got round the issue of running specific sql scripts in the
> setUp()/tearDown() methods by calling Ant programmatically with a buildfile
> containing the required code. Works really well and means we can use Ant
> functionality in our test cases.
> 
> Thanks
> 
> Rakesh

The answer can change depending on the needs of the specific test
(actually the object under test).

If you are testing business rules and don't want to burden your tests
down by writing to the database (who would want to) you can use mocks. 
We have a factory for getting connections to the database.  These
connections are homebrews which hold on to JDBC connections.  For
testing we get a MockDatabaseConnection and assert for updates, inserts,
deletes, table creations, table drops, etc. on the mock connection.

If you are testing that your SQL statements work (reading from this
table, writing to that table, etc.) and that the underlying assumptions
of the tables/views in question are valid, then you probably need real
access to the database.  We have these kinds of tests as well.  They
test our Query classes to make sure they can read the database --
selects are correct, joins, unions, etc.  We have Record classes that
know how to write themselves to the database, so we have them write to a
test bed and assert on the shape of the data pre- and post- write.

We also have our own system for pooling and clearing connections.  So,
to test these mechanisms we use mocks where possible and allow for real
database access to a test bed where mocks will not suffice.

I hope that helps.

Jason
